I've owned this for two years, and every time I come back to it I'm playing for days.  Yes, there are only four environments in it (looking forward to more in Climb 2) but each has numerous different paths to take.  And even if you know the way up each one, there is always a continuing challenge to take new holds or skipping past others, esp. as its necessary to unlock the 5-minute progress awards.  

I especially enjoy climbing in the Bay environment, as I vacationed in a very similar spot in Thailand three years ago.  The scenery is spot-on, and the launch of the paper lanterns was very much part of that trip.  It's like going on vacation all over again.

The North trail ("Icebreaker", I think) is fantastic in its sense of scale and terror.  Climbing along the side of a rusty ship hull, lodged precariously above a stream of lava, there's a sense of immediacy to every grip you take.  Especially as some of those aren't easy to see, and you have to commit to a jump that could easily spell doom.  Reaching the top of this stage leads to a striking cinematic event, and I found myself sitting down on the platform for five minutes watching it unfold.

All in all, this sort of game is unique in that it doesn't focus on fast pace or  immediate reward.  Well, small rewards in that the each grip is an accomplishment.  But the pacing of each climb makes for a very different experience than most other games I've played.  Bring on Climb 2!

The levels progressively get more and more complex, with different routes and some shortcuts if you are up to it. The whole point of the game is to complete the climb as fast as possible, but there's a gamemode that completely removes the timer and stamina if you just want to enjoy the view.

Only negative I have? I want more locations. I need more. As someone who used to free-climb in Arizona, rock-climbing/mountain-climbing is such a fun and thrilling experience. I really wish they'd continue to add more stages, but alas, you get what you get.

It went on sale for $20.00 and I grabbed it.  It was totally worth it.   Its really fun and has beautiful scenery. Update: Fast foward a couple years later and I got a new computer (12th gen Intel CPU) but this game was crashing on load.  I found the solution on Reddit.  It has something to do with OpenSSL and newer generation CPUs.
Follow these steps:

Go to System --> Advanced System Settings --> Environment Variables (You might get to this differently in different versions of Windows)

In THE SECOND window ("System Variables") click NEW

Enter name "OPENSSL_ia32cap"

Enter value "0x200000200000000"

Then click OK

You must REBOOT SYSTEM

This solved the crashing problem I was having with several Oculus VR apps and several Steam VR apps.

Titles on VR, I honestly think this is one of the best games in VR, the graphics, expeience and atmosphere, truly line up well together. Disclaimer : I used to be an avid climber and playing this, even before the touch version came out, was one of the best most enjoyable experiences I've had in VR.

This game really wowed me. I've had my rift for over a year and have played a lot of different games on it but this is easily one of the most impressive. Honestly, I hesitated for so long buying this game because I doubted they could pull off the feeling of climbing a cliff in VR and also thought, how challenging and fun can it be? It turns out that it is QUITE challenging and fun! First of all, they nailed the mechanics. You really feel like you are hanging precariously from a cliff and forget you are standing in a room of your house. The fatigue system works quite well and the number of different handhold types and precarious situations you get into make it quite thrilling. Nothing like having to jump to an out of reach handhold across a chasm and just managing to grab it with one hand. Also, the graphics really make you feel like you are in an exotic locale. The game also has high replayability improving your score and unlocking achievements in the various locations and difficulty levels. This game is the closest you're going to get to the feeling of being a cliff climber in VR.

Most of the gameplay as expected comes from just getting a better time and score, so if you aren't the type who like climbing scoreboards, best give this game a miss. And though I have seen few VR games with such detailed environments, it is hardly worth $40 if you aren't going to be fully impressed by it (for those with a few dozen hours in VR, for instance). Finishing all the levels probably took me about 4 hours and since I haven't touched in a month. It doesn't have much to make you want to go back to.

review_title: Very immersive with a few flaws
one_reviews_text:
I kinda have a fear of heights and the game takes full advantage of it. Hanging on a cable over a deep valley valley looking out for the next grip and realizing there is none within reach... unless I make a huge jump to that cable car. I actually didn't want to believe that I had to make that jump. This and other moments were pure adrenaline. 

The Climb is a looker. Beautiful environments, detailed rock surfaces and quite some events happening around you. Graphically it's also a very demanding game and it really shines if you crank up the supersampling.

There are only a handful of different environments, but each contains a couple of stages and challenges which feel varied enough.

The climbing mechanics feel good, especially if you know that the game could only be played with a normal controller when it was released. The later added touch controls improved the experience a lot. Like it's almost a different game now.

But it has its flaws. The black screen when your head collides with objects, especially important things like ladders or beams can get very annoying. The approach Lone Echo has taken with pushing you away from the object is way more convenient.

Also the risky jumps you have to make are pretty tough to estimate. A lot of times I bumped against the rocks above me and fell. You also can't control intensity of the jump.

Other than these issues and that the nature of the game is kind of repetitive, I can only recommend the Climb. The developers tried a lot to keep each stage fresh with new and surprising routes and challenges. Also making it to checkpoints often rewards you with some nice events like skydivers rushing above your head or an erruption of a mountain in the distance. Or you just enjoy the beautiful vista.

Can't wait to try out the Oculus Quest port which is also a cross-buy title and free if you already own the Rift version.

Fantastic graphics, great VR implementation now with the Touch controls, lots of content, challenge, secrets to find, stuff to unlock.  But one completely unavoidable mechanic really spoils the game for me - virtual jumping.  First, while they have a way to do more realistic jumping where you push yourself off something, in many places this isn't functional and you have to use the "A button" jumping mechanic.  I could overlook the lack of immersion (and complete lack of realism that having 95% of these jumps brings) that causes, but it is just so incredibly unreliable.  From hitting your virtual head on objects and immediately falling, etc.  The mechanic could have been made playable if when holding the A button you saw a "ghost" image of where your body would go/the arc of the jump, but unfortunately at this point I'm sure nothing more will be added to the game.

Lastly the peformance can be ropey sometimes, some active elements like rocking ladders and little scenes like bears or birds can make the game drop frames, but most of the time it's okay. review_title: Exciting game with an exasperating flaw!
one_reviews_text: "The Climb" is easily one of the best VR experiences I've had and it alone is worth the price of the Oculus. The concept and gameplay are simple; but it's far from boring, especially if you have a fear of heights.  Not that the devs needed to make it more involved; but they added fun pick ups on some of the mountains to keep it interesting. When you fall, you feel it. When you get to the top of the mountain, there's a genuine sense of accomplishment.  This would be a five star game if it weren't for one terrible flaw. That is, when your virtual character "clips" with an object in the game (a part of the mountain behind you, for instance), the screen goes black and you'll get a message stating that you've intersected something and you need to move.  Ummmm....ok; but I'm hanging on the side of a mountain and because the screen is black, I can't find the next handhold.  What's bad is that, by design, you have to climb under things that will naturally clip you (an overturned ladder, for instance). This is EXCEPTIONALLY bad when trying to jump from one handhold to the next (which you do a lot) because in mid-jump, the screen will go black (because you'll clip an object above you) and it's impossible to aim for the next handhold.  Grabbing onto it is a matter of blind luck.  I don't mind failing if it's a misjudgement on my part; but if it's because of an obvious flaw on the devs part, it's maddening.  Either allow the player to clip objects or show the message at the bottom of the screen and give the player the ability to find their way out of the situation. Despite that rant, it doesn't take away the fact that this game is frikkin awesome!

As a rock climber that climbs 5.12 lead and boulders around a V7 grade I avoided this title like the plague since getting the Rift.  Climbing is all about the physical aspect guided by climbing technique.  There is no way that a VR experience can reproduce even the slightest nuance of what it takes to climb.

That said, I saw it go on sale and thought 'what the he11'.  So I fired it up to see what it's all about and although I just did one level I was a bit taken aback how it might actually turn out to be a fun experience despite initial misgivings.

The first thing I noticed is how big, clumsy and creepy the hands look and feel but I got over that.  The other big thing that's missing for any type of climbing simulation is feet.  It's probably not possible to implement feet - or say 98% of any real climbing motions at all actually - due to the lack of physical feedback, but I wasn't really going in expecting that anyway.  What we're left with is a 'campusing' (hanging from your hands/fingers no feet) simulator puzzle.

Despite those major limitations it does manage to give some idea of how to think your way through a route/problem, and manage your strength to some degree.  Having to sometimes awkwardly reach for holds is as nicely done as they are able to and can be a great introduction to the sport to people who wouldn't otherwise realize how much more better and fun it is as a way to get in shape than crossfit or weight lifting.  Watch any of these ninja warrior like competitions and see what training style dominates. ;)

Dynos (jumping) are awkward but give you a taste of the thrill of them, and it's pretty cool to stand on the final platform and enjoy your virtual accomplishment.  The graphics aren't bad either.

I think I will enjoy the rest of the game and environments for what they are and hope that it will introduce this amazing and surprisingly safe, sport to more people.

I really looked forward to playing this, so I bought it and installed it while I was at work. Once I got home to play it, I spent a long time inside the environment and really enjoyed it. I did 4 climbs on the first level and feel that I understand the mechanics of the game well enough. Visually, they did a great job on it, the Physically Based Shading is really nice to see in a VR game.

Here is what I didn't like:
1) There are quite a lot of times when there is HDM collisions with rocks, and it causes the screen to just go black.
2) It's too easy to accidentally hit the Oculus home button when trying to use the Jump command
3) There was a good bit of stutter, which is quite a shock to me running on a 1080.

I've played just the first level so far. Although not everyone will be able to handle The Climb's unique form of locomotion (using your hands to move the world), it is a title that manages to capture much of the emotion of actual climbing - the sense of danger, of struggle, of achievement. I really appreciate their attentiveness to options for gender and skin tone, and the new Touch support feels great. This is a game where Touch really works better than Vive because it feels more like you're using your actual hands to climb. Although it does not begin to emulate the actual strength and athleticism required of actual climbers, there is a lot more effort in standing and raising and moving your arms than sitting in a chair with a gamepad. My only issues were minor: there's no tutorialization of mechanics (it only shows you which way to go), and I was slightly annoyed at my character's celebration audio at the top because I preferred to celebrate myself.

My Thoughts:
Ok first things first.... Crytek is one of my favourite game developers so I was very excited to be able to play this game.
WOW! This game just totally blown me away.... it's 'by far' one of the best VR experience I've had since purchasing my Oculus. The sets and locations are stunning and the gameplay is exhilarating, a word I hardly use for any game. If this is the type of quality and experience we can expect from future VR titles, then the future is very exciting indeed.

Game Details:
Scale huge heights and feel the exhilaration of extreme free solo climbing. Conquer towering rock formations inspired by areas of natural beauty in North America, Europe, Asia, and the Arctic Circle. Explore and enjoy the view or compete for the fastest times on leaderboards with Touch or gamepad controls. Developed by Crytek and achieved with CRYENGINE™.
 
Free solo climbing – Experience the adrenaline rush as you ascend to epic heights, explore caves, find shortcuts, and more.
Multiplayer and achievements – Race other players’ ghosts, rise up leaderboards, and earn over 100 achievements to unlock gear. 
Bouldering – Beat intense routes that demand perfect technique. 
Tourist mode – Climb with simplified mechanics, ideal for introducing friends to VR.
Outstanding environments – Feel the thrill in four beautiful, immersive locations by day or night.
